source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: An ingot of double consumable electrode vacuum melted material was first hot forged. Part of the hot-forged bar was then hot extruded, vacuum annealed, and cold drawn in several passes to obtain rods; another part of the hot forged bar was vacuum annealed and cold hydrostatically extruded in a single pass to form rods.
process_step: double consumable electrode vacuum melted, hot forged

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Part of the hot-forged bar was then hot extruded, vacuum annealed, and cold drawn in several passes to obtain rods
process_step: hot extruded, vacuum annealed, cold drawn

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: another part of the hot forged bar was vacuum annealed and cold hydrostatically extruded in a single pass to form rods

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: the properties and microstructure of ingots for the cold drawn rods were better than those of cold hydrostatic extrusion

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: hafnium-free zirconium sponge was double consumable electrode melted under vacuum to produce a Zircaloy ingot
process_step: double consumable electrode melted under vacuum

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: When defects (voids) in the material are being healed, the material becomes more dense and the density of the material increases

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Microvoids were observed by metallographic microscopy

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The rod diameters after hydrostatic extrusion were, respectively, $1 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ and $1 6 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ for the tensile test and the ductile fracture toughness test
test_type: tensile test, ductile fracture toughness test

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The rod diameters after hydrostatic extrusion were, respectively, $1 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ and $1 6 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ for the tensile test and the ductile fracture toughness test
test_type: tensile test, ductile fracture toughness test

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: the properties of the former should be better than those of the latter

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: hydrostatic extrusion is carried out under high pressure, under optimum stress condition, and with good lubrication, resulting in material with improved microstructure

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Tubing of Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4 produced by the laser beam beta-phase treatment is immune to nodules on both the inside and outside surfaces in the $^ { 2 4 \mathbf { h } }$ , $\mathbf { 7 7 3 \ K }$ steam test

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: post-transition corrosion rates of Zircaloy-4 are lower than those of conventionally processed tubing by factors of two to three in the 633 to $\bf { 6 7 3 ~ K }$ temperature range

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The Zircaloy-2 and -4 compositions were selected primarily because of their favorable aqueous corrosion resistance relative to unalloyed zirconium

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: the corrosion resistance of Zircaloy is sensitive to microstructure and, hence, processing history

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Early autoclave data indicated similar corrosion responses of $\pmb { \alpha }$ annealed and $\beta$ -treated Zircaloy during exposures in 589 to $\bf { 6 7 3 ~ K }$ water and/or steam

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: At higher corrosion temperatures of approximately ${ \bf 7 3 ~ K }$ , however, a marked improvement of $\beta$ -treated over $\pmb { \alpha }$ -annealed Zircaloy was reported

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: $\beta$ -annealed Zircaloy-2 was resistant to nodule formation and oxide spallation for up to 36-days exposure in $^ { 7 7 3 \bf K }$ , 11.7 MPa steam
property_name: nodule formation resistance, oxide spallation resistance

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: as-fabricated Zircaloy-2 was susceptible to nodules after one day in $^ { 7 7 3 \mathrm { \bf K } }$ steam

source_id: STP939-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_7th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: $\pmb { \alpha }$ -annealed material was susceptible to enhanced oxidation and oxide spallation after as little as 7-days' exposure in $\mathbf { 7 7 3 ~ K }$ steam
